statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Northwestern 56, Portland 53
article.story: FAIRBANKS, Alaska (AP) -- T.J. Parker hit a running 3-point shot as time expired as Northwestern beat Portland 56-53 in the first round of the Top of the World Classic Friday night. Parker led the Wildcats (1-0) with 18 points. Vedran Vukusic added 12 and Davor Duvancic had nine rebounds for Northwestern. The Pilots (0-1) were led by forward Marcus Lewis' 14 points and 11 by Pooh Jeter. Lewis also had 11 rebounds. Lewis tied the game 53-53 with a short jump shot with 3.6 seconds left. But then Parker took the inbounds pass, dribbled up court and took the wide-open shot to finish the Pilots. Both teams made 39.6 percent of their field goals, but Northwestern struggled from the free-throw line, going 4-for-10. The Wildcats were 10-for-34 from the 3-point line, with Parker shooting 3-for-6 and Vukusic 2-for-2. Vukusic also had a game-high five assists. Portland outrebounded the Wildcats 41-26, but turned the ball over 17 times. Northwestern led by as much as 12 in the first half, but allowed Portland to charge back for a 30-28 lead at the half. The Pilots continued their run in the second half, leading by as much as nine midway through. But Northwestern put together a 14-5 run to end the game.
